boardgame.name: Antike Duellum
Antique Duellum
Casus Belli
boardgame.description: Antike Duellum _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;ndash; previewed at Spiel 2011 under the name Casus Belli _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;ndash; is a two-player strategy game based on modified rules from Mac Gerdts' Antike. The game includes two scenarios: Punic Wars (Rome vs. Carthago) on one side of the board, and Persian Wars (Greeks vs. Persians) on the other. The goal of the game is to be the first to gain nine ancient personages (Kings, Scholars, Generals, Citizens, Navigators)._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Examples of modified rules from Antike:_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; Modular layout - when a player founds a city, he chooses whether it produces Iron, Marble, or Gold_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; Over 20 event cards, which provide more variety in the game_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; Town walls for individual protection of cities_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; Each _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot;Know-How_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot; costs a different amount - for example, inventing the market is more expensive than inventing the wheel_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; A new Know-How for trading goods with the bank_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; Higher costs for legions and galleys - they are first recruited from the bank to the personal supply (paying gold)_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; Easier rules for conquering cities with no movement of units_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;
boardgame.boardgamehonor: 2013 Golden Geek Best 2-Player Board Game Nominee
2013 International Gamers Award - General Strategy: Two-players Nominee
boardgame.boardgamepodcastepisode: Podcast #060 - Al Calvo por fin le gusta Race for the Galaxy

original bilingual (D/GB) PD-Spiele edition new and shrinkwrapped in perfect condition

Rio Grande Games (RIO486) Both players lead an ancient civilization. On one side, the Carthaginians play against the Romans and on the other side, the Greeks play against the Persians. Each nation starts with three cities, whcih produce Marble, iron, and gold. These resources are used to develop the civiliztions. A nation can build town walls with marble. It can develop technologies and recruit military units with gold. Iron is used to arm and equip the legions and galleys. The nations expand their territories by moving their legions and galley to found new cities. Players may also use their legions and galleys to conquer their opponents_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039; cities. Knowledge of new technologies may double movements, boost defensive strength, and strengthen economies. The first player to own 9 personages will win the game.
